comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Major John Oliver Naismith gained the rank of Major in the service of the Royal Field Artillery. He married Maria Cecilia Bell (b1889), daughter of Thomas Anthony Bell and Esther Love Brown, in 1917.thepeerage.com/p13846.htm Army Educational Corps Capt. J.O. Naismith DSO retires, receiving a gratuity 4th Feb 1926, and is granted the rank of Maj. The London Gazette 5 February 1926 Major John Oliver Naismith - a major from the first world war with a degree in Divinity. He was headmaster 1926-1941 of John Watson's School, a small non-fee-paying co-educational boarding school in Edinburgh "and had become something of an institution. He was always immaculately dressed and out of doors his bowler hat, tightly rolled umbrella and spats worn over shoes polished to Army standard set him apart from ordinary mortals." There are anecdotes here about the Major. He left John Watson's at the end of the Easter term in 1941 after 15 years service. BBC Home. WW2 People's War. Evacuation - A Novel Aspect by David Brown www.bbc.co.uk/ww2peopleswar/stories/95/a1955595.shtml

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Captain John Oliver Naismith, holding a Special Reserve Commission, was promoted to Major, while in command of a Battery, with effect 25 Sep 1916. LG 29993 of 20 Mar 1917. Immediately after the Armistice he was appointed to an instructor appointment at the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst as an Acting Major with effect 13 Nov 1918. LG of 20 Dec 1918.//

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: John Oliver Naismith was cremated 9 Dec 1961 at Warriston Crematorium (Edinburgh) Maria C Naismith died 5 Mar 1972 and was cremated 8 Mar 1972 at the same location. www.deceasedonline.com
